info.author: Daniel Carmon
info.description:
# steptrace
Traces which python lines are being execuded

    usage:
        python -m steptrace mycode.py
    this will run mycode.py, printing each executed line

    E.g, if mycode.py is:
        def foo(x):
            return x+1
        a = foo(3)
    then output of 'python -m steptrace mycode.py' will be:
    ~path~/mycode.py(1) def foo(x):
    ~path~/mycode.py(4) a = foo(3)
    ~path~/mycode.py(1) def foo(x):
    ~path~/mycode.py(2) ret = x+1
    ~path~/mycode.py(3) return ret
    ~path~/mycode.py(3) return ret
    ~path~/mycode.py(4) a = foo(3)
    (Steptrace) The program finished.

    How this module works:
    the code is heavily based on Pdb.
    Basically, we're just using Pdb with two main differences:
        1) User input is automaticaly set to be 'step'
        2) Printing only the lines in the given file. see usage.

    There is ALOT of room for improvement!
    Feel free to contact me at:
        daniel.carmon91@gmail.com
info.name: steptrace
info.summary: Run python code and print lines being run
info.html_description:
steptrace

Traces which python lines are being execuded

usage:
    python -m steptrace mycode.py
this will run mycode.py, printing each executed line

E.g, if mycode.py is:
    def foo(x):
        return x+1
    a = foo(3)
then output of 'python -m steptrace mycode.py' will be:
~path~/mycode.py(1) def foo(x):
~path~/mycode.py(4) a = foo(3)
~path~/mycode.py(1) def foo(x):
~path~/mycode.py(2) ret = x+1
~path~/mycode.py(3) return ret
~path~/mycode.py(3) return ret
~path~/mycode.py(4) a = foo(3)
(Steptrace) The program finished.

How this module works:
the code is heavily based on Pdb.
Basically, we're just using Pdb with two main differences:
    1) User input is automaticaly set to be 'step'
    2) Printing only the lines in the given file. see usage.

There is ALOT of room for improvement!
Feel free to contact me at:
    daniel.carmon91@gmail.com
